burn.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if a fire burns, it produces heat and flames
burn.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: There was a fire burning in the fireplace.
An average household candle will burn for about six hours.
burn.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: if something is burning, it is producing flames and being damaged or destroyed by fire
burn.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Parts of the building are still burning.
burn.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to destroy or damage something with fire
burn.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I burnt all his old letters.
Cars were burned and shops were looted during the rioting.
The Grand Hotel had burnt to the ground.
Make sure the iron isn’t too hot or you’ll burn the cloth.
He dropped his cigarette and burnt a hole in the carpet.
burn.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to hurt yourself or someone else with fire or something hot
burn.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I burned my hand on the oven door.
She was badly burned in a road accident.
Sixteen passengers were burned to death (=died in a fire).
A family of five were burned alive in their home last night  (=died in a fire).
Heretics were burnt at the stake (=burnt in a fire as a punishment).
burn.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if the sun burns your skin, or if your skin burns, it becomes red and painful from the heat of the sun
burn.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Don’t forget you can still get burnt when you’re swimming or when it’s cloudy.
Her face and neck were quite badly burned.
burn.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to spoil food by cooking it for too long, or to become spoiled in this way
burn.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I’m afraid I’ve burnt the pizza.
The meat was burned to a crisp.
burn.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to damage or destroy something by a chemical action
burn.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Quite a lot of household chemicals can burn your skin.
burn.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if you burn a fuel, or if it burns, it is used to produce power, heat, light etc
burn.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The boiler burns oil to produce heat.
greenhouse gases caused by the burning of fossil fuels
burn.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if you burn fat or calories, you use up energy stored in your body by being physically active
burn.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Taking a brisk walk every morning is a great way to burn calories.
burn.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if a light or lamp burns, it shines or produces light
burn.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: A lamp was burning in the kitchen window.
The hall light was still burning.
burn.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if a part of your body burns, or if something burns it, it feels unpleasantly hot
burn.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: The whisky burned my throat as it went down.
My eyes were burning from the smoke.
burn.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: if your face or cheeks are burning, they feel hot because you are embarrassed or upset
burn.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: I could feel my cheeks burning as I spoke.
burn.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: if you burn a CD or DVD, you record music, images, or other information onto it using special computer equipment
burn.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: a sports car burning up the motorway
burn.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 3: to hurt yourself or someone else with fire or something hot
burn.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: His face had been badly burned in the fire.
The animals were burned alive when a farm building caught fire.
Anyone inside the truck would have been burned to death.
In those days witches were burned at the stake.
burn.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0]: Burn belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
burn.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1]: In this sentence, ‘the toast’ is the object of burn
burn.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2]: In this sentence, ‘the toast’ is the subject of burn
burn.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: to be burning
burn
to produce heat and flames
The fire was still burning.
A pile of branches was burning in the yard.
be on fire
if a building, car, piece of clothing etc is on fire, it is burning and being damaged
Before long, the neighbouring houses were on fire too.
be alight
if something is alight, it is burning
By the time the fire engines got there, the whole building was already alight.
The candle was still alight.
be ablaze
if something is ablaze, it is burning with a lot of flames, so that it is seriously damaged
Twelve hours after the bombing raid, many parts of the city were still ablaze.
The two hundred tonnes of straw were now ablaze and firefighters struggled to get the fire under control.
blaze
to burn very brightly with a lot of flames and heat
A big log fire was blazing in the fireplace.
smoulder
to burn slowly and continuously, producing smoke but no flames
A cigarette smouldered in the ashtray.
The fire in the chemical factory was so intense that it was still smouldering a week later.
flicker
if a fire or flame flickers, it burns with an unsteady light that appears and disappears quickly
A welcoming fire flickered in the grate.
Inside the shrine candles flicker next to statues of saints.
to start burning
catch fire
to start burning accidentally
We were worried the house would catch fire.
Two farm workers died when a barn caught fire yesterday.
burst into flames
to suddenly start burning and produce a lot of flames that cause serious damage
The plane crashed into the side of the mountain and burst into flames.
ignite
if a chemical or gas ignites, it starts burning
The compound ignites at 450 degrees Celsius.
Scientists could not explain why the gas had suddenly ignited.
to burn something
burn
to damage or destroy something with fire or heat
She lit a fire and burned his letters one by one.
set fire to something
to make something start burning so that it gets damaged
Vandals set fire to an empty warehouse.
Teresa wondered if the burning log might set fire to the curtains.
The Vikings attacked villages along the coast and set them on fire.
Sparks from the fireplace could easily set the curtains on fire.
scorch
to damage the surface of something by burning it so that a dark mark is left on it
Having the iron on a very high heat can scorch the fabric.
The heater was left on all night and it scorched the wall.
singe
to damage hair, wool, paper etc by burning it slightly so that the ends or edges are burnt
The flames were hot enough to singe your eyebrows.
scald
to burn your skin with very hot liquid or steam
The coffee was so hot it nearly scalded his tongue.
It’s easy to knock a pan off the stove and scald yourself.
He was scalded by steam escaping from the broken pipe.
ignite
to make something start to burn, especially something that burns easily such as a gas or chemical
The gas is ignited by an electrical spark.
It appears he threw away a lit cigarette which ignited the petrol spilt on the ground.
to make something stop burning
put out
to make something such as a fire, cigarette, or candle stop burning
It took firefighters four hours to put out the blaze.
She threw sand on the fire to put it out.
I put out my cigarette and went back into the house.
extinguish
to make something such as a fire, cigarette, or candle stop burning
He managed to extinguish the flames with his coat.
Customers who smoke will be asked to extinguish their cigarettes or leave the premises.
blow out
to make a flame or fire stop burning by blowing on it
He blew out the candle and went to sleep.
The wind blew out the fire.
burn.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an injury caused by fire, heat, the light of the sun, or acid
burn.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: His body was covered in cigarette burns.
She is being treated for minor burns.
She was taken to the hospital with serious burns.
Several of the survivors suffered severe burns.
burn.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a mark on something caused by fire or heat
burn.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The desk was covered with graffiti and burn marks.
burn.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a painful mark on the skin caused by it rubbing hard against something rough
burn.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to copy information held on a computer’s HARD DRIVE onto a CD ROM
burn.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to lose a lot of money in a business deal, usually because it involves a high risk
burn.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: A lot of investors got burned buying junk bonds which turned out to be worthless.
burn.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to suffer from the results of an unsuccessful business activity
burn.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Since burning their fingers on 100% lending that turned into bad debt, lenders have been limiting borrowing to 75% of the property’s value.
